title: 108_s573
content: The Act is titled the "Organ Donation and Recovery Improvement Act". Congress expresses its sense regarding organ donation and recovery. The "Organ Donation and Recovery Improvement Act" emphasizes the importance of public awareness, family discussions, and living donations of organs. Congress urges the government to educate the public on organ donation, encourage families to discuss becoming donors, and recognize the contributions of living donors in saving lives through organ transplantation. The Public Health Service Act is amended to allow reimbursement for travel and subsistence expenses related to living organ donation. The Secretary may award grants for reimbursement of travel and subsistence expenses for living organ donors. Preference is given to those unable to meet expenses, and certain circumstances may be considered. The Secretary may consider certain circumstances when awarding grants for reimbursement of travel and subsistence expenses for living organ donors, including individuals incurring qualifying expenses towards organ donation without the donation occurring, and expenses for accompanying individuals. The award will not cover expenses already paid by state compensation programs, insurance policies, or health benefits programs, prepaid health service providers, or the organ recipient. Definitions for donating individuals and qualifying expenses are provided in this section. Authorization of appropriations is also mentioned. Authorization of appropriations is mentioned in subsection (c)(2), with $5,000,000 authorized to be appropriated annually from 2004 to 2008 for carrying out this section. SEC. 4. PUBLIC AWARENESS; STUDIES AND DEMONSTRATIONS. Part H of title III of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include a new section 377A for public awareness, studies, and demonstrations. The Secretary will establish a public education program to increase awareness about organ donation. Grants may be provided for studies and projects to boost organ donation rates. States may receive grants for organ donor awareness and outreach programs. States must submit an application, set yearly benchmarks for organ donation improvement, and report to the Secretary annually on fund usage. Funds can be used for education, awareness, donor registry activities, and innovative initiatives, including living donation. The Secretary will coordinate educational activities with relevant networks. The Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network will develop educational materials on organ donation for healthcare professionals. $15,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2004, with additional funding for 2005-2008. "Grants for hospital organ donation coordinators are authorized under SEC. 377B." The Secretary may award grants to qualified organ procurement organizations and hospitals to establish programs coordinating organ donation activities of eligible hospitals. Eligible hospitals are those that perform significant trauma care or serve a population base of at least 200,000 individuals. A condition for receiving a grant is that the program will be carried out jointly. The program under the subsection will be carried out jointly by representatives from the eligible hospital and the qualified organ procurement organization, along with other designated entities. Entities receiving a grant must establish joint leadership responsibility, develop performance goals, and implement a data collection process for ongoing feedback. The Organ Donation and Recovery Improvement Act allows for collaboration between eligible hospitals and organ procurement organizations to increase organ donation rates. Grants will be evaluated within 3 years to assess their impact. Matching requirements for grant recipients are also specified. The Organ Donation and Recovery Improvement Act requires grant recipients to provide non-Federal contributions amounting to at least 30% of the grant awarded. Funding of $3,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 is authorized, with additional appropriations for fiscal years 2005 through 2008. SEC. 377C. STUDIES RELATING TO ORGAN DONATION AND THE RECOVERY, PRESERVATION, AND TRANSPORTATION OF ORGANS. The Secretary will develop scientific evidence to support organ donation efforts and improve organ recovery, preservation, and transportation. This includes conducting evaluation research, reviewing scientific literature, and ensuring research evidence is utilized in clinical practice guidelines. The Secretary, through the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, will support research and dissemination of findings to develop a uniform clinical vocabulary for organ recovery and utilize information technology to enhance organ procurement organizations' clinical operations. The Secretary will support organ procurement organizations by enhancing workforce skills, assessing organ technologies, and authorizing appropriations for fiscal years 2004-2008. SEC. 6. REPORT RELATING TO ORGAN DONATION AND THE RECOVERY, PRESERVATION, AND TRANSPORTATION OF ORGANS. Part H of title III of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include a new section 377D for a report on organ donation and organ transportation. The Secretary must report to Congress every two years on Department activities related to organ donation and recovery, evaluating their impact on donation rates. Reports should assess effectiveness, identify successful activities, and track progress on implementation plans. Initial reports must include specific requirements. The Secretary must report to Congress every two years on Department activities related to organ donation and recovery, evaluating their impact on donation rates, including an evaluation of organ donation practices, living donation practices, and federally supported organ donation efforts and policies. The Secretary must report to Congress every two years on Department activities related to organ donation and recovery, evaluating their impact on donation rates, including an evaluation of organ donation practices, living donation practices, federally supported organ donation efforts, policies, research, coordination across relevant agencies, costs and benefits of State donor registries, and a plan to improve federally supported organ donation and recovery activities. The Secretary must report to Congress every two years on Department activities related to organ donation and recovery, evaluating their impact on donation rates and coordinating federally supported organ donation and research activities. SEC. 7. NATIONAL LIVING DONOR MECHANISMS. The Secretary can establish mechanisms to evaluate long-term effects of living organ donations. SEC. 8. STUDY. By December 31, 2004, the Secretary must submit a report to Congress on the ethical implications of proposals to increase cadaveric donation. SEC. 9. QUALIFIED ORGAN PROCUREMENT ORGANIZATIONS. Section 371(a) of the Public Health Service Act is amended by removing paragraph (3) to promote organ donation. This amendment was passed by the Senate on November 25, 2003.
